terms.definition: A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems.
Comprehensive written materials that explain how a product works, its features, and how to use it effectively.
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing multiple people to collaborate while maintaining a history of revisions.
Individuals or groups who have an interest in or are affected by a product or project, including customers, employees, and management.
Pre-designed document formats or structures that can be reused and customized for creating consistent documentation.
The process of creating, organizing, storing, and maintaining digital content in a systematic way.
Software platforms that enable multiple users to work together on documents or projects simultaneously.
Electronic versions of documents that can be easily shared, edited, and accessed online rather than in physical format.
The capability of software or documentation to be translated and displayed in multiple languages for global audiences.
The visual elements and controls that allow users to interact with software applications or digital platforms.
The process of converting written material from one language to another while maintaining meaning and context.
The feature that allows managers to delegate specific work items to team members within a collaborative platform.
A feature that enables users to leave feedback, suggestions, or notes on specific parts of a document or content.
A central location where data, documents, or code is stored and managed, often with access controls and organization features.
A specialized software solution designed specifically for creating, managing, and sharing technical documentation and knowledge bases.
